I have a theory on why we see a flash and why the bullets disintegrate. We're used to seeing wave forms in the air and in water but I think what we don't see are hypersonic waves through solids. When the bullet touches the glass, it has its own internal frequency from the deflagration of being shot. It exits the barrel carrying that solid energy, touches an object and shares that energy at hyper speeds, goes all the way down the glass and bounces back shattering the bullet and the glass. We can't see it. I think the flash is trillions of molecules being so condensed from the hypersonic energy that it makes a bright light. Components have to have compacted molecules for this to happen. Idk, my theory.

I'm not sure how sir Francis Bacon came to be known on the internet as the "father of the scientific method". He was an Aristotelian philosopher and did promote it, but by the time he was alive it had been a standard of science for 600 years.  I think it is an amalgam of Francis Bacon, 16th century philosopher, with Roger Bacon, 13th century scholar and monk who read the works of Alhazen (10th century Arab mathematician and scientist) and who spread widely the anti-Aristotelian notion that we cannot trust our intuition to arrive at correct observation, instead laying out the basics (hypothesis-experiment-control-result) that would later be picked up by Descartes and Pascal in the early 17th century to arrive at the scientific method we know today. Francis Bacon spent half his life as a barrister and, while he promoted the scientific method, neither invented it nor defined it in any way. He would have read about it in Alhazen's works on optics, and sung its praises to his readers, but in the field of philosophy and science, it was already old news by his time. I know there are many sources across the internet that describe him as the "father of the scientific method" but I think it is important to note that all those sources are American or British, while sources in other languages all point to Alhazen instead. It is a pity that what can be described as anglo-centrism leads to wiping away important aspects of our heritage, including the Arabs who made decisive contributions to mathematics and science, including giving us algebra and the number system we use today, and the Indians, who literally taught the western world including Romans and Greeks how to write, made ceramic, and make steel.

Check out adhesive tape (masking tape, duct tape, etc) in the dark. When tape is removed from what it's stuck to in the dark, it displays light along the juncture where it is breaking free. Triboluminescence?
Years ago, when doing darkroom work, I noticed the glow while removing tape holding 120 photographic film from its paper backing. After developing, exposed areas on the film where tape had been could also be seen. I presumed the glow was a result of weak molecular bonds between the tape's adhesive and the mated surface. I used to suggest that it was static electricity that made tape sticky and nobody would believe me.
Similarly, when tape or other materials are torn in the dark, light can be observed where the break is occurring. More triboluminescence?

Direct piezoelectricity of some substances, like quartz, can generate potential differences of thousands of volts. The best-known application is the electric cigarette lighter : pressing the button causes a spring-loaded hammer to hit a piezoelectric crystal, producing a sufficiently high-voltage electric current that flows across a small spark ...The first piezoelectric effect was initiated in the year 1880 by the brothers Jacques Curie & Pierre. By adding their piezoelectricity knowledge with the behavior of crystal structure they confirmed this effect by using examples of piezoelectric crystals like quartz, tourmaline, cane sugar, Rochelle salt, and topaz.

I know I'm late to the discussion, but Prince Rupert's drop is actually fairly fragile, because its structure trades stability at one end for instability at the other.  You can see this in the slow-mo of the first AK-47 shot.  The drop doesn't disintegrate from where it was struck, instead collapsing tail-first.  That's because the stability at the head relies entirely on the tail, and because the tail is fragile enough to break without ever being touched directly.

I'm no chemist but my theory as to why light is produced when the bullet hits the glass has to do with electron orbitals. You can see the light travel through the glass, proving that it is not a single pulse of light so the initial source is not from the bullet's impact. Rather, it's possible that as energy courses through the tail of the drop and electrons are pulled towards highly electronegative oxygen atoms, light is released as electrons fall to a low-energy state and emit photons.

In order for Si to form 4 bonds, one of its 3s electrons must be excited and go into a higher-energy 3p orbital. Si then forms bonds with oxygen. As energy ripples through the glass, electrons are attracted towards oxygen nuclei and end up in a more stable 2p orbital. This releases light. This leaves Si cations and O anions. Si ions would react with free oxygen in the air and get reduced while oxygen anions get oxidized and possibly break off of the crystal to form oxygen gas in a higher-energy state than it began as. Essentially, the bullet's energy could be converted to electrical potential and light and oxygen gas.

But that's just a slightly educated guess which is likely riddled with flaws 🤷‍♂️

You are coming up with the wrong conclusions.    When the bullet hits the drop right in the middle, the drop survives the initial impact but breaks up when the impact wave back-propagates back to the drop and there is nowhere for the energy of the wage to go.   When the bullet does not hit the drop in the middle, there are two waves: one with the movement of the bullet and  second one perpendicular to the movement that travels the width of the drop, which is a very short distance, back-propagates and comes back quickly and makes the drop explode very early.    But in all cases the drop survives and the bullet explodes way before the drop explodes.    Look at the video to confirm.

I am a huge fan of this channel - seriously. But now I'm wondering. I realise that it is maybe second nature to Americans - like breathing air - such that they never even noticed but I found the ready familiarity with the guns and rifles … well, unsettling. (And I suspect that many non-Americans will feel likewise.) Clearly there is no suggestion of any from of irresponsibility far less violence but never having seen any of these weapons (outside of a museum) far less handled them, I felt - well, unsettled. If the test (which I otherwise found very interesting) had been set up in a laboratory and carried out in a scientific manner, then the examination of the high velocity projectile on a Prince Rupert's drop would have sat perfectly comfortably with me. But a range of guns and rifles casually arranged loosely on the tailgate of a pickup with bullets fired off into the fields was … well, I can only say again, unsettling.

My 2 cents... I was listening to Neil DeGrasse Tyson explain a theory about how scientists had questioned the "cosmic shooting gallery" hypothesis of the early solar system citing the lack of evidence of glancing blows from comet strikes on the moon. All craters on the surface of the moon were perfectly circular in shape and therefore it must be from volcanic activity rather than comet strikes. This led the scientist to the realization and discovery of the fact that when an object collides with another,  such as when a comet collides with a planetary body, if the comets terminal velocity reaches a point to where the total impact will be stronger than the forces that hold the molecular bonds together, the result will be an explosion rather than a "simple" impact. Obviously I'm no NDT, but thats basically what he said.  He gave the example of the meteor crater in Arizona having no meteorite material in the bottom of it when miners searched it; when that comet/asteroid/meteoroid hit the surface of the earth it simply vaporized instantly because the resulting forces ripped apart both the comet and the surrounding landscape down to a molecular level. I bring this up because in the one shot where you say "I don;t know what just happened" it seems as though you hit the drop dead on with a high velocity round. Could it be that there was enough energy transfer to create the type of impact mentioned above? Idk and I don't pretend to know but that's what came to mind when I watched it. Granted this is a bullet and glass, and the example that NDT gave were mile plus long comets traveling several miles per second but its, nonetheless, similar.

As a electronics and mechatronics major, my educated guess on what causes the triboluminescence, is that the crystalline candy is displaying properties of piezoelectric crystals.
An example would be the spark from lighters without the flint and wheel (like BBQ lighters.) A small hammer that is driven by a spring strikes the piezoelectric crystal, which then creates the spark. Piezoelectric crystals create a charge between opposing surfaces when pressure or impact occurs across the two surfaces of the crystal.

I'm curious what your definition of "beat a Prince Rupert's Drop" is. Yes, the drop shattered, but so did the bullet. Given the purpose of a bullet, it seems to me the Prince Rupert's Drop countered the bullet, which begs the question, "Can a Prince Rupert's Drop stop a bullet from penetrating ballistics gel?"  I could envision a Prince Rupert's Drop embedded in a block of ballistics gel with the head of the drop protruding. I would also cut a slit into a single layer of Kevlar and slide it over the head of the drop, covering the block of ballistics gel. If the bullet and the shrapnel do not penetrate the ballistics gel, my conclusion would be the Prince Rupert's Drop defeated the bullet. It would then be interesting to see how high of a caliber you could go up to before the bullet and/or the shrapnel penetrate the ballistics gel.

Great vid!! I would like to politely disagree with the theory that the first A/R bullet (and probably the second but you can't see it) breaks the PRD. The PRD stayed intact long enough to explode the A/R bullet. ( blew my mind!) While I'm not sure how to explain this, I believe what happened was the PRD stayed intact from the bullet hit, but the sudden movement compromised the weaker tail. Picture the crack of a whip. The sudden movement of the heavier, and stronger, part of the drop whipped the tail, which is less strong, causing the tail to go, initiating the implosion of the PRD. I don't know how to explain mechanics of it but I think the sudden inertia imparted on the large end while the tail end trying to stay in place triggered the demise of the drop. See theory that, Objects in motion stay in motion while objects at rest, want to stay at rest. I'm sure you know what I'm trying to say, I just don't have the knowledge to explain it as eloquently as you can. I am interested in your thoughts on my theory if you wouldn't mind responding to me. Dear Destin,

We are Marcos and Annalee. We live in southern Mexico and our parents are homeschooling us. Marcos is 13 and Annalee is 11. We have thoroughly enjoyed watching your series on the Prince Rupert's drops and their reaction to having bullets fired at them. The slow-motion shots are really cool!

Here are some paragraphs that we wrote with our dad, Tim, about some of our observations and predictions about the Prince Rupert's drop.

The Prince Rupert's drop is made by dropping molten glass into a container of water. In the process of cooling, the outside cools rapidly because of its immediate contact with the water but the inside cools more slowly. As the drop cools, this causes a tension differential the deeper you go into the drop. We read on the Internet that the outer 10% of the drop is where the greatest tension, and therefore strength, is located.

We watched some other videos that investigated the speed at which glass shatters. We found that regular glass and tempered glass shatter at about 1600 meters per second. In your video you showed calculations of the Rupert's drop shattering at about the same speed. Since the Rupert's drop was so much harder than regular or tempered glass, we predicted that it would shatter much faster, but it doesn't. We were surprised to find that the increased tension does not increase the speed at which the glass shatters.

We are wondering if it would take eight times the pressure to shatter a 1 inch diameter Prince Rupert's drop than it would to shatter a 1/2 inch diameter Prince Rupert's drop since there is an approximately eight fold decrease in volume.

On the Internet, we tried to find the pressure required to crush a Prince Rupert's drop. We found a variety of answers, anywhere from 10 tons to 100,000 psi.

Do you think that the pressure will be different if the volume of the drop is different?

We are, like you, trying to get Smarter Every Day!

Marcos and Annalee

Regarding the light seen with sugar and glass, this could be due to piezoelectric properties.  I'm not sure about the glass drop but the sugar does have piezoelectric properties.  So does quartz (silicon dioxide - SiO2) and SiO2 is a primary component of glass.  However, I think that the piezoelectric effect is only seen in crystalline materials, so again, I'm not sure about the glass.  Thousands of volts can be generated just by putting pressure on these materials.  The igniters on gas grills, lighters, etc. use a piezoelectric crystal to start a flame.  I think that is what caused the sparks with the Life Savers.  Great video...

Just going through the physics in my mind. For the one that the tail came off, it looks like the shock wave travelled down the tail until the narrowing tail concentrated the force engulf to fracture the class.  The shock wave would be radially symmetric at that point. Other methods of breaking the glass tend to not be radially symmetric.  The radial symmetric glass would separate leaving the stresses in radial equilibrium. Of course, that's a pretty complicated theory so it is probably wrong.

For clarity... First, I assume 223,000 FPS is frames per second, not feet per second.  Still an impressive video capture rate.  223,000 feet per second would  be 'silly' fast... well exceeding orbital escape velocity.   I suspect some readers have made this error.  Second, it looks like (at least to me) that the 'triboluminescence' effect is simply an example of the well known piezoelectric effect.  The direct conversion of mechanical energy into electrical energy (and vice versa) is commonly used in BBQ spark igniters, sonar systems and sensors.  I am doubtful that a glass 'drop' would have a piezoelectric effect because of the lack of crystalline structure.

The first time I saw triboluminescence was on a field trip to the Performing Arts Center in my state. I can't remember the grade but I think it was 8th or 9th and they were showing Peter Pan, not that any of that matters. Anywho, obviously it was dark in the theater and there was this guy sitting next to me who said "Hey, watch this, it's cool". He puts a piece of candy in his mouth, was a mint LifeSaver or maybe a Certs mint, I don't know which, again not that it matters. He puts it between his teeth and bites down causing the cool little blue light show called triboluminescence. I was amazed! Destin...When you shot the PRD with the AK47 the second time, there is another interesting thing I see. The bullet connects with the drop at about .600ms. You can see the triboluminescence reflected in the opposite end of the drop at least twice in the next few moments. And then, around .700ms, with the wave front moving distally from the impact site, the other crack front beginning at the tail collides with the first wave before it can reach the tail. Although I don't have the exact dimensions of the drop you used, the information of the bullet's impact would travel through the PRD at the speed of sound (in a PRD), and you can therefore estimate that speed in a PRD to be faster than the wave front speed and probably somewhere around 6000-8000 fps. I believe the sparks you are saying are for unknown reason must be due to the piezoelectric effect. Every mecanical action on a piezoelectric results in an electrical reaction. This is used for clocks and it is based on a precise way of cutting quartz crystals. And that is one of may uses, Maybe sugar is piezoelectic on this crystal form. Based on that, from wikipedia I found "The first demonstration of the direct piezoelectric effect was in 1880 by the brothers Pierre Curie and Jacques Curie.[7] They combined their knowledge of pyroelectricity with their understanding of the underlying crystal structures that gave rise to pyroelectricity to predict crystal behavior, and demonstrated the effect using crystals of tourmaline, quartz, topaz, cane sugar, and Rochelle salt (sodium potassium tartrate tetrahydrate). Quartz and Rochelle salt exhibited the most piezoelectricity."
Murica!

Destin, I would say that triboluminescence is the product of or the result of the release of energy that is stored in crystals. John Hutchinson who is most noted for discovering the effect that bears his name i.e. The Hutchinson Effect, which you would really find intriguing, also found that if you place crystals in a small cylinder under some pressure they will release a flow of energy indefinitely. John used this principle to make some small batteries that released around a half volt and are still going strong some 30+ years later. Anyway, John is an interesting character and perhaps he and his effect would make an episode of Smarter Every Day.

What I find fascinating about this particular video is this: https://youtu.be/k5MORochIDw?t=5m19s

You can se clearly that with this impact, the wave of shattering glass travels from both ends. Both from the front of the drop where the bullet impacted it, and from the back of the drop, the tip of the tail.

We've seen this before in the previous video where a fragment of glass struck the tail and created two directions of shattering shock wave. However, it's clear in this video that the fragments did not travel fast enough to do this.

What else is clear from this point around 5 minutes and 19 seconds in, is that the triboluminesence occurs simultaneously at the front and at the tip of the tail of the drop.

What else is interesting is that it's clearly this tribolumninesence that causes the initial shockwave from the tip.

Furthermore, it's clearly not the initial triboluminesence, but some subsequent event.

Did the light traveling down the drop collect together at the tip and create so much heat that thermal distortions caused the glass to break? Or is there something subtler happening here?

Hi, Destin! I've really enjoyed your Prince Rupert's Drop videos.
I'm curious why you think it was triboluminescence that caused the flash/light when the drop shattered. I hope that is the cause (because it's so cool), but couldn't it also be caused by sunlight scattering through the many, tiny shards? The drops shatter so spectacularly, creating what looks like very fine shards that stay at a high density for a very short amount of time. It seems possible to me that the density and irregularity of the shards could act almost like mist, scattering the sunlight and creating a bright, flat, white light.

I think I might know why it's breaking, and it isn't from the sheer force of the bullet. If you look at the exact moment of impact, before triboluminescense occurs, there is an orange flash of light. However, said orange flash wasn't there with the AK round, but if you look at the angle at which the bullet hit it seems to glance-off more than the other two. Now, the strength of a Prince Rupert's drop comes from it's insane internal pressure and gives it equally insane surface tension strength, but imagine what would happen if something melts the glass, even if it's only by a tiny amount? I think that's what is happening here; the bullet hits the drop with such force that the resulting friction heats the glass up just enough to allow the surface to melt, breaking the surface tension and therefore the drop. I have an idea on how you could possibly test this too: incendiary rounds, specifically from the smaller caliber guns. If it really is just brute force overcoming the surface tension, the smaller caliber guns in your last video shouldn't be able to break the drops even with the added energy from the incendiary charge (I'm suggesting using smaller bullet that imparts much less energy, that way the variable of bullet power being the reason for them breaking wouldn't be as much of a factor). However, if I'm right and it's more to do with the heat from friction, then maybe a drop made from Pyrex (if it can be created in the same way sodalime glass is and still form the same molecular structure) or another type of glass with a higher melting point would be even stronger.

Back in 1988 (maybe 1989), at Halloween I visited Cal Tech with my roommate, who was an alumnus.  The students soaked some pumpkins in liquid nitrogen and dropped them off the roof of the library.  The idea was everyone would get to see the flash of blue light from triboluminescence as the crystallized pumpkin got smashed.  Well, there was no flash of light, but the very first pumpkin shattered into pieces, one of which squarely hit a guy in costume in a very sensitive area.  He went down for the count.

I think it's really cool how Paisly writes letters in a mirror image. This isn't just a "cute childish" thing.
